Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Legal_Issue: Do the respondents meet the residency requirements under s. 5(1)(b) of the Citizenship Act for Canadian citizenship?
Application_Facts: Respondents accumulated only 22 and 60 days of physical presence in Canada, respectively; claimed permanent residence but lacked substantial integration into Canadian society or institutions.
Decision_Outcome: Respondents do not meet the residency requirements
Remedy_Requested: Secretary of State appealed to rescind the Citizenship Court's decision
Court_Ruling: Appeals allowed; Citizenship Court's decision rescinded
Defendant_Behavior: Limited physical presence in Canada due to religious duties abroad
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient physical residency despite claim of maintaining permanent residence
Legal_Standard: Three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence, integration into Canadian society, connection to Canadian institutions
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Court to Federal Court
Credibility_Assessment: Claim of permanent residence deemed insufficient without evidence of integration
Evidence_Used: Records of physical presence, claims of maintaining residence abroad
Application_Basis: Accumulation of residency days and demonstration of ties to Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of physical presence, nature of residential ties
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have at least three years of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of substantial presence or integration in Canada
Harm_Assessment: Risk of granting citizenship contrary to statutory requirements
Cause_Description: Applicants applied for citizenship while spending most time abroad fulfilling religious duties
Evidence_Handling: Court assessed credibility and sufficiency of residency claims
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient documentation or proof of actual residency
Evidence_Assessment: Weight given to physical presence over claimed residence
Decision_Rationale: Statutory residency requirement is objective and requires measurable physical presence
Evidentiary_Issues: Inadequate evidence to support claim of effective residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective test of physical residency under s. 5(1)(b)
